description:
The aim of this course is to highlight the most
important areas of policy analysis in which insights
from behavioural economics have fruitfully been
applied. It discusses the underlying behavioural
theory, and shows how this can be applied to policy
analysis. A strong focus of the course is to outline
methods and discuss results that focus on empirically
testing and quantifying non-standard motives. We
also discuss how such policies can be piloted and
evaluated within an evidence-based policy
framework. The course also showcases how
behavioural insights are used in public policy for
Singapore.
title: Behavioural Public Policy
